questions.question: When transitioning from a 1:1 model to a group coaching model, which metric is most critical for evaluating the efficiency of the transition?
options: Total number of followers
Revenue Per Coaching Hour (RPCH)
The number of manual emails sent
Cost per click on social media ads
questions.explanation: Revenue Per Coaching Hour (RPCH) allows a coach to see the financial leverage gained by serving multiple clients simultaneously compared to the fixed time-for-money 1:1 model.

questions.question: In the context of a 'Digital Product Ecosystem,' what is the primary function of a 'Tripwire' offer?
options: To provide a free resource in exchange for an email
To convert a lead into a paying customer with a low-friction, high-value purchase
To serve as the final, most expensive tier of the value ladder
To automate the booking of 1:1 discovery calls
questions.explanation: A tripwire is a low-cost (typically $7-$47) product designed to convert a prospect into a customer quickly, establishing a financial relationship and increasing the likelihood of future high-ticket purchases.

questions.question: Operational Excellence requires automation. Which tool is specifically highlighted for its ability to 'glue' different software systems (like a CRM and an LMS) together without manual data entry?
options: Zapier
Canva
MyFitnessPal
WordPress
questions.explanation: Zapier is an automation tool that connects disparate apps, allowing for 'Zaps' that trigger actions in one platform based on events in another, which is essential for scaling operations.

questions.question: When pursuing Strategic B2B Partnerships with medical clinics, what is the most important legal consideration for a coach operating in the United States?
options: Ensuring the clinic uses the coach's specific brand colors
HIPAA compliance for the secure handling of Protected Health Information (PHI)
Obtaining a secondary business license for every state
Setting up a referral commission that exceeds 50% of the program cost
questions.explanation: HIPAA compliance is mandatory when handling medical data or receiving referrals from healthcare providers to ensure patient privacy and legal protection for both parties.

questions.question: What is the primary difference between 'Methodology Licensing' and a 'Franchise' model as discussed in Lesson 5?
options: Licensing allows the coach to retain Intellectual Property (IP) while granting others the right to use it, usually with less operational control than a franchise.
Franchising is always cheaper for the coach to set up.
Licensing requires the coach to manage the daily staff of the licensee.
There is no difference; the terms are legally interchangeable.
questions.explanation: Licensing is a way to scale by selling the rights to use your proprietary methodology or content, offering more flexibility and less operational overhead than the rigid structure of a franchise.

questions.question: According to the psychological principles of 'Immersive Retreats,' why are they considered high-ticket offerings?
options: Because they include expensive organic catering
Because the high price tag is the only reason clients see results
Because they remove clients from environmental triggers and habit cues, facilitating rapid behavioral change
Because they require the coach to fly to international locations
questions.explanation: Immersive retreats allow for 'pattern interrupts.' By removing clients from their daily environments, coaches can implement new plant-based habits more effectively, justifying the premium price through superior outcomes.

questions.question: When building a coaching team, what is the recommended 'Coach-to-Client' ratio to maintain high-quality outcomes in a scaled group program?
questions.explanation: While group models scale, maintaining a ratio of 1 coach per 25-30 clients ensures that participants receive enough individual attention to prevent churn and ensure clinical success.

questions.question: To ensure long-term business health, the ratio of Customer Lifetime Value (LTV) to Customer Acquisition Cost (CAC) should ideally be:
options: 1:1 (Breaking even)
At least 3:1 (LTV is triple the CAC)
0.5:1 (Spending more to acquire than the client is worth)
1:10 (Spending 10x more on marketing than revenue)
questions.explanation: A 3:1 LTV to CAC ratio is considered the industry standard for a healthy, scalable business, ensuring that the profit from a client significantly outweighs the cost to find them.

questions.question: A coach is preparing for an 'Exit Strategy' and wants to maximize their business valuation. Which of these makes the business MOST attractive to a potential buyer?
options: The business is entirely dependent on the coach's personal brand and face.
The business has high 'Key Person Dependency.'
The business has documented SOPs (Standard Operating Procedures) and automated recurring revenue.
The business has never used a CRM or tracked data.
questions.explanation: Buyers look for 'turnkey' operations. A business with documented systems (SOPs) and recurring revenue is much more valuable than one that relies solely on the owner's personal presence.

questions.question: Case Study: Coach Sarah has 40 1:1 clients and is working 60 hours a week. She wants to double her income while reducing her hours to 30. Based on Module 35, what is her best first step?
options: Raise 1:1 prices by 10% and work more hours
Stop all coaching and only sell a $20 eBook
Transition current 1:1 clients into a high-leverage group coaching program with a structured curriculum
Hire 5 new coaches immediately before creating a system
questions.explanation: Transitioning to a group model allows Sarah to serve more people in fewer hours (leverage). This should be done before hiring a team to ensure the methodology and systems are proven first.
